item.title: Feb 08 Class
item.description: We began with a bit of history, noting the emergence of field-recognition techniques and contrast between the “field marks” and GISS or BBI approaches. Then we focused how to pay attention to and talk about size, shape, and structure, including relative size and proportions. Learning species (for quiz next week) These were the species for which we carefully examined differences. Downy Woodpecker Hairy Woodpecker Common Loon Red-throated Loon Also on the quiz Shown an image of a perched bird: “Make a short list of at least four structural features of this bird that might be helpful in identifying it.

item.title: Feb 01 Class
item.description: (This page is under development) -- We will meet in our Friday classroom, which is different from both your Monday classroom and our Friday lab space. It is 103 Brower (campus map location). Learning species (for quiz next week) American Robin Northern Mockingbird Also, learn the vocabulary terms on the distributed sheet, to be able to recognize where they go on a picture of a bird. You can use the bird topography diagrams in your Sibley book to study this (and you can find alternative diagrams online).

item.title: Class Information
item.description: Our Friday classes will be at 11:15–12:40 in 103 Brower (campus map location). Usual timeline Our 85-minute class sessions will normally be structured like this: quiz (up to 15 minutes) an identification topic (about 25 minutes) learning identifications (about 40 minutes) Quiz Each week we will have an identification quiz at the beginning of class. The quiz will consist of ten identifications. Most of the identifications will be species (or other taxa) learned the previous week.
